Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: Innovation, diversification, and complexity: The impact of venom evolution on the integrated venom delivery system of snakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2017, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. The Fellow?s research focuses on a key gap in our knowledge of how the diversity of extant life came to be. There is a conflict between the complex traits of organisms, such as the architecture of the head, jaws, and teeth, and the speed at which new species appear over evolutionary time. The major hypothesis for the rapid appearance of new species is the idea of key innovations, which are traits that provide novel ecological opportunity to a group of organisms. However, these traits are part of a complex organism with other traits that may constrain the evolutionary path that is possible. The Fellow?s work will determine if morphological constraints breakdown following the appearance of key innovations in the venom of North and South American snakes. The Fellow will visit several museum collections to quantify variation in head and fang shape of pitviper species, and quantify levels of variation in these traits to determine if changes in snake venom lead to changes in variation and complexity in the venom delivery system, or if the opposite is true. The Fellow will then use 3D printed fang models to determine if fang shape contributes to the toxic actions of venom, which will help us understand snakebite morbidity in humans. This research will train the Fellow in 1) cutting edge research methods in the different fields of molecular evolutionary biology and morphology, 2) mentorship of four graduate and eight undergraduate students who will also learn new methods, and 3) developing outreach programs that bring scientific knowledge out of the lab and to interested citizens. The research will also preserve thousands of valuable museum specimens as digital photographs and lead to the development of a teaching module on key innovations in snake venom for use in the high school and college biology classroom.

The key trait approach focuses on a few traits in isolation, while most traits are inherently complex and interdependent. This interdependence (i.e. phenotypic integration) is manifest as sets of integrated phenotypes (i.e., modules) that vary independently of each other. The extent of phenotypic integration and modularity in a set of traits can, itself, evolve, but the relationship between integration, evolutionary innovations, and biological diversity has not been determined. This research will test the hypothesis that rapid biological diversification is intimately linked with altered patterns of integration and modularity in key traits in New World venomous snakes. The Fellow will achieve the following goals: (1) quantifying the degree of association between diversification rates and the strength and pattern of phenotypic integration in head and fang morphology, (2) determining whether biochemical innovations in the venom are linked to morphological divergence, and (3) using micro-CT scans and 3D printed fang models to test for the hypothesized functional relationship between fang morphology and venom composition. The Fellow will be trained in comparative evolutionary analyses, geometric morphometrics, micro-CT, 3D printing, and mentoring of other young scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the relationship between the formation of new species and the evolution of novel traits is of crucial importance to explaining the diversity we observe in nature. Previous work has identified many so-called key traits – traits that, when gained through evolution, impact the rates of formation of new species. Many of these key traits are simple or easily defined by a single function, while the reality of organisms is that they are complex combinations of many traits. This project investigated the relationship between multiple complex traits, natural selection pressures, and diversification across viperid snakes, such as rattlesnakes, copperheads, and adders. We asked whether the burst of diversification seen in pitvipers after the development of the heat-sensing pit organ and subsequent invasion of North and South America might have been facilitated by altered patterns of trait complexity and trait interrelationships (termed phenotypic integration).

To achieve this overarching goal, we took measurements of the heads and fangs of more than 2000 preserved museum specimens of 199 species of viper from around the globe. We first investigated the relationships among fang, head, and body size, and found that the relationship between head and fang size in snakes is quite strong, although there are 3x differences in relative fang size between the smallest and largest-fanged species. Contrary to our hypothesis that the more rapidly diversifying lineages would have larger amounts of variation in relatively fang sizes, there was no clear trend toward such a pattern in any viper lineage regardless of diversification rate. Instead, relatively longer fangs occur in snakes that feed on more mammals, suggesting a strong role for variation in natural selection pressures from diet in impact fang length and integration of fang and head size.

Head shape is more complex than fang shape, and we used photographs of the same preserved museum specimens to measure head shape variation. The relationship between snout shape (which contains sensory organs and fangs) and shape of the back of the head (containing venom glands) showed patterns more consistent with our hypothesis that rapidly diversifying lineages show lower levels of phenotypic integration in a key trait – this case evolution of the snout and back of head occurs more independently in  Old World vipers compared to the New World pitvipers. Much of this work is ongoing, and forthcoming analyses will further interrogate relationship among venom composition, head shape, fang shape, and the environments in which these species live.

As an NSF Postdoctoral Fellow, I received a much valuable training and experience. I was mentored in bioinformatics and evolutionary analysis, computer-aid design and 3D printing, teaching a graduate-level course, instructional design, and issues surrounding diversity and inclusion in STEM fields. In addition, I had the opportunity to train and mentor 9 undergraduates research students, who are in various stages of completing independent research projects associated with the goals of this grant. Two of these have already authored a scientific manuscript that importantly has shown that the complex shifts in the venom of snakes that occur as they grow occur gradually rather than all at once when snakes become adults, which has important implications for producing effective anti-venoms from captive-raised snakes. I also mentored 5 graduate students, teaching them skills in bioinformatics, study design, dissemination of their results, and scientific outreach to the broader public.

In addition, this project has resulted in the installation of a permanent museum exhibit at the Tallahassee Museum of natural history on the relationship between fang evolution and diet in Florida’s venomous snakes, and that educates visitors about the ways in which we use both museum specimens and phylogenetic (evolutionary) trees to study natural processes. My work on this project has also led to the development of educational modules geared toward graduate bioinformatics, and high school and undergraduate exploration of the nature of science through exploration of snake fang evolution and the development of anti-venoms.
